Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent procedure and has slightly elevated vital signs.
Story:
I sat on the edge of our bed, my husband’s hand trembling in mine. His eyes were red, his voice barely above a whisper as he tried to make sense of the news he’d just received. He needed me—needed my words, my arms, my steady presence. I could feel the weight of his pain, and I wanted nothing more than to stay, to reassure him that he wasn’t alone.

But my phone buzzed on the nightstand. The hospital. I was on call, and a patient recovering from surgery had slightly elevated vital signs. The nurse on the other end sounded worried; they needed me to come in, to check and record the patient’s temperature, pulse, and blood pressure. My mind raced. My husband’s grip tightened, silently pleading for me not to leave. At the same time, I knew my patient depended on me for their safety and care.

Torn between the two, I felt my chest tighten. Both needed me, both expected me to be present, to give my all. I stood there, caught in the middle, heart pounding, unable to move.
